text:
House Republicans passed a bill yesterday 
to raise the government's borrowing limit.

And the Walt Disney Company has filed a 
lawsuit against Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis.

Good morning, I'm Korva Coleman, from NPR 
News, and here are today's top stories:

Republican-backed legislation that would increase 
the debt limit is now heading to the Senate.

NPR's Windsor Johnston reports it passed the 
House yesterday with no Democratic support:

"The House passage could set the stage for 
another round of negotiations between Speaker

Kevin McCarthy and President Biden, 
who haven't spoken since February.

Majority Leader Chuck Schumer has repeatedly 
warned that the bill, which ties a borrowing

limit increase to deep cuts in government 
spending, will go nowhere in the Senate:

'The GOP's Default on America Act, as we 
call it, does not bring us any closer to

avoiding a first-ever default; in fact, it only 
brings us dangerously closer to defaulting.'

Biden on Wednesday said that he will not meet 
with Speaker McCarthy about the debt limit,

calling the issue 'not negotiable.' 
Windsor Johnston, NPR News, Washington."

President Biden has held the second White 
House state dinner of his presidency. Last

night's event was for South Korea's leader 
and celebrated the 70th anniversary of

the alliance between the U.S. and South 
Korea. NPR's Marie Andrusewicz reports:

"Nearly 200 guests were in attendance 
for the black tie dinner in honor of

South Korea President Yoon Suk-yeol. The 
list of notables included actor Angelina

Jolie. Following a dinner featuring crab 
cakes and ribs, the guests were treated

to live performances of Broadway tunes. Then 
President Yoon offered a tribute of his own:

(Yoon sings: "A long, long time ago / I can still 
remember / how that music used to make me smile")

The song is one of the South 
Korean president's favorites.
Marie Andrusewicz, NPR News, Washington."

The Walt Disney Company is suing Florida Gov. Ron 
DeSantis and other officials. The company says

the Republican governor's orchestrating a plan of 
government retaliation simply because the company

said things that DeSantis did not like. It's the 
latest in a tit-for-tat exchange — last year,

the Disney Company objected to Florida's so-called 
"Don't Say Gay" law. NPR's Greg Allen says

DeSantis responded by urging Florida lawmakers to 
act against Disney's property rights in Orlando:

"DeSantis is urging Republican lawmakers, passed 
a bill that stripped Disney of its self-governing

authority, but before that law took effect, 
Disney signed a deal with its outgoing board

allowing it to retain development rights 
on the 40-square-mile district. Yesterday,

the new board met near Orlando and 
voted to invalidate that deal. The

board's lawyers detailed what they said 
were procedural missteps made by Disney

that they believe make the agreement void and 
unenforceable, and moments after that vote,

Disney filed its lawsuit against DeSantis 
and other officials in federal court."
NPR's Greg Allen prepared that report.

A Montana lawmaker has been banned from 
the State House chambers. Montana Public

Radio's Shaylee Ragar reports this follows 
a protest that disrupted business on Monday:

"Montana House Republicans all voted in favor of 
sanctioning Rep. Zoe Zephyr for her support of

protesters who filled the chamber on Monday. The 
protesters were there in response to Zephyr, who

is transgender, being blocked from speaking after 
making remarks on a bill to ban gender-affirming

care for minors. Republican leaders say Zephyr 
violated the rules of decorum when she held her

microphone above her head, aiming to amplify 
the shouts of protesters. That was after the

House Speaker ordered the chamber to clear. Zephyr 
says the Republicans' actions are undemocratic:

'All you are doing is using 
decorum as a tool of oppression.'

Zephyr will be allowed to participate 
in committee meetings and vote remotely

but not debate. For NPR News, 
I'm Shaylee Ragar in Helena."
You're listening to NPR News.
